definition: Word choice and vocabulary level, ranging from simple to complex, concrete to abstract, common to technical

positive_examples: The elevated diction ('commence' rather than 'start') establishes formality.
Concrete diction ('oak tree') vs abstract diction ('nature') affects vividness.
Technical diction signals expertise but may alienate general readers.
The poet's diction is monosyllabic and Anglo-Saxon rather than Latinate.
training_hints.disambiguation: Specific patterns of word selection, not just having vocabulary
